June 23, 2002: Fiction
IN THIS MOUNTAIN, by Jan Karon. (Viking, $25.95.) In the seventh book of the
"Mitford Years" series, Cynthia Kavanagh thrives in retirement while her husband,
Father Tim, grows restless.
FIRE ICE, by Clive Cussler with Paul Kemprecos. (Putnam, $26.95.) Claiming to
be a descendant of the Romanovs, a mining tycoon tries to overthrow the Russian
government.
THE SHELTERS OF STONE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $28.95.) Love and danger
in a prehistoric society; the latest volume in a series that began with "The Clan of
the Cave Bear."
THE NANNY DIARIES, by Emma McLaughlin and Nicola Kraus. (St. Martin's,
$24.95.) A satirical look at rich and powerful New Yorkers through the eyes of an
Upper East Side nanny.
MORTAL PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $26.95.) Lucas Davenport searches
for a hit woman from his past who herself has become the target of a killer.
THE WAILING WIND, by Tony Hillerman. (HarperCollins, $25.95.) Sgt. Jim Chee
and Joe Leaphorn try to solve a homicide case.
DADDY'S LITTLE GIRL, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) An
investigative reporter discovers new information about her sister's murder.
THE EMPEROR OF OCEAN PARK, by Stephen L. Carter. (Knopf, $26.95.) The
patriarch of a black family, forced to withdraw from consideration for the Supreme
Court, dies under mysterious circumstances.
THE SUMMONS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A law professor
discovers more than $3 million in cash in his father's study.
STAR WARS: EPISODE 2 -- ATTACK OF THE CLONES, by R. A. Salvatore.
(Lucas/Del Rey/Ballantine, $26.) The Republic edges toward disaster.
A THOUSAND COUNTRY ROADS, by Robert James Waller. (John M. Hardy,
$19.95.) A sequel to "The Bridges of Madison County."
JOLIE BLON'S BOUNCE, by James Lee Burke. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) Deputy
Dave Robicheaux investigates two rape-murders in a Louisiana bayou town.
SIN KILLER, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) In 1830, the
Berrybender family leaves England behind and heads for the American frontier.
CONFESSIONS OF A SOCIOPATHIC SOCIAL CLIMBER, by Ad√®le Lang.
(Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $22.95.) The day-to-day activities of a scheming,
self-centered advertising copywriter in London.
Non-Fiction
STUPID WHITE MEN, by Michael Moore. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $24.95.)
The man behind "Roger & Me" takes aim at Republicans and Democrats,
corporate America and our "nation of idiots."
THE RIGHT WORDS AT THE RIGHT TIME, edited by Marlo Thomas. (Atria, $25.)
More than 100 celebrities describe a turning point in their lives.
MASTER OF THE SENATE, by Robert A. Caro. (Knopf, $35.) The third book in a
multivolume biography of Lyndon B. Johnson, covering the years 1949 to 1960.
A MIND AT A TIME, by Mel Levine. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A professor of
pediatrics examines the learning patterns of children and the various ways in
which parents and other adults can help them succeed.
FIREHOUSE, by David Halberstam. (Hyperion, $22.95.) A journalist's report on
what one group of New York firefighters experienced on Sept. 11.
ODD GIRL OUT, by Rachel Simmons. (Harcourt, $25.) A study of the secret lives
of girls and the culture of female aggression.
LUCKY MAN, by Michael J. Fox. (Hyperion, $22.95.) A memoir by the film and
television actor, who was told a decade ago that he had Parkinson's disease.
MEDAL OF HONOR, by Allen Mikaelian. (Hyperion, $25.95.) Profiles of American
military heroes who served in the Civil War, World War I, World War II, Korea and
Vietnam.
FIND ME, by Rosie O'Donnell. (Warner, $23.95.) The actress and talk show host
discusses her childhood, her motherhood and, especially, her long-distance
friendship with an unwed teenage mother-to-be.
JOHN ADAMS, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of
the country's first vice president and second president.
LAST MAN DOWN, by Richard Picciotto with Daniel Paisner. (Berkley, $24.95.)
The highest-ranking firefighter to survive the attack on the World Trade Center
describes the ordeal of Sept. 11.
AMERICAN SON, by Richard Blow. (Holt, $25.) The last years of John F. Kennedy
Jr., as seen by a former editor at George magazine.
ONCE UPON A TOWN, by Bob Greene. (Morrow, $24.95.) The story of North
Platte, Neb., which millions of American servicemen passed through during World
War II.
WEALTH AND DEMOCRACY, by Kevin Phillips. (Broadway, $29.95.) From the
Revolution to the 21st century: a political history of the American rich.
